text:
Amul has evolved from a dairy to a nutrition brand and is probably the most underrated case study in modern day business. They did a revenue of 90,000cr in FY25. Hard to think of another company in the world that has done something similar. Notes on what i think they got right..

1) They innovate at cooperative speed not startup speed and still wins. Launched 250 product launches in 5 years and that's crazy speed for a cooperative with millions of farmers, 18000+ village societies, and government-linked processes. Most companies will shiver at this speed.

2) They turned cold chain into a moat decades before most startups spoke about supply chain tech. They run Indiaâ€™s largest cold supply chain with refrigeration networks across rural area and temperature controlled logistics in small towns. This single capability lets them enter any nutrition category quickly.

3) The nutrition transition feels like farmer driven. More milk production means surplus fat & SNF (casien, whey , lactose) and therefore opportunity to create value added products. Every new category like whey, chocolates, drinks, cheese, creates more value for farmers. Most nutrition brands optimise for margins but they optimise for farmer income.

4) Amul is probably the only brand that simultaneously sells mass and premium products all under same brand,  same dairy and distribution and with same trust. Their products range for Rs 5 to 500. Most brands split into sub brands while Amul let the trust carry everything.

No obsession with burn, CAC ,CM1/2 growth and branding. They quietly proved that trust, scale and farmer first thinking can still beat everyone.

text:
America just put a $100,000 price tag on the Indian dream. Never been a better time than now for Indian engineers to build at home. The US was the promised land for Indian engineers but not anymore. And India isnâ€™t the India of the 90s when engineers moved out for better pay and exposure. 

Earlier generations left India because they didnâ€™t have a choice. Today, staying back is the smarter choice. The US is telling the world that they want fewer immigrants, at higher prices & under tighter conditions. 

In the 1960s & 70s, US actively recruited Indian doctors and engineers to fill shortages. In the 90s & 2000s, IT/software outsourcing made H-1B the obvious path for thousands of engineers. In reality, the India of today is not the India many left behind. 

This is not to say India is without its own constraints. We still have infrastructure gaps and bureaucracy is still frustrating.
But if you look back at history, Indian engineers have always thrived precisely in moments of constraint. 

The outsourcing opportunity of the 90s was born from wage arbitrage. The SaaS opportunity of the 2010s came from building global software with frugal & distributed teams. Each cycle has taken adversity and Indian entrepreneurs turned it into advantage.

The next cycle will be no different. The very inefficiencies of India around fragmented supply chains, healthcare gaps, broken education models will be the anchor to build world class companies. To solve for India is to solve for the future of other emerging markets.

This is the great inversion of our time and for the first time in history, the opportunity cost of leaving India may be greater than the opportunity cost of staying.

The last generation of Indian engineers built Americaâ€™s tech backbone. The next generation has the chance to build Indiaâ€™s. Come back home. Time to build for India and from India.

text:
Every week, I get a 10 new startup pitches that says â€œWeâ€™ll deliver healthcare in 10 minutes.â€ Quick commerce is now rushing into healthcare. So I thought to do a breakdown on whatâ€™s hype and what might actually work in India. 

What could work?
1)30â€“60 min medicine delivery can work for chronic refills or acute needs. In metros with dense demand, it's useful. But 10-min isnâ€™t necessary. Even same-day is fine for 90% of use cases. And honestly, your local chemist is already doing that.

2) Rapid diagnostics for home blood collection isnâ€™t about speed but itâ€™s about hygiene and reliability. A 2-hour sample pickup and next-morning results is a solid win. What we need is better logistics and trained phlebotomists, not faster scooters.

3)On-demand nursing or paramedic visits but for use cases like wound care, IV, injections. Could work with proper scheduling. Think â€œOla for nurses,â€ not â€œBlinkit for bandages.â€ Needs backend infra for verification, training, EMR integration.

What wonâ€™t work (At least not now)
1) Ambulance in 10 mins sounds great until you hit Delhi or Bangalore traffic. Speed is useless without triage and location accuracy. What we really need is better coordination between hospitals and ambulance providers, not just faster wheels.

2) On-demand doctors in 10 mins is a bad idea. You donâ€™t need any doctor fast but you need the right one. Discovery & matching are bigger problems than speed. Most video consults struggle with quality, not timing. Clinical care isnâ€™t fast food. Trust takes time.

3) The 10-min everything app for healthcare is lazy ambition dressed up with VC money. Healthcare isnâ€™t a SKU game but itâ€™s complex, regulated, and hard to standardize like groceries. Great for funding buzz, terrible for trust and real outcomes.

Few thoughts if you really are passionate to build in healthcare. 
Trust > velocity.
Speed isnâ€™t everything.
Infra & people ops > APIs.
Reliability > 10-min hacks.
Health is longitudinal & not transactional.

Good luck if you're building something in Healthcare in India.

text:
Doctors in India die earlier than their patients. I know it sounds crude but what it means is Indian doctors have a life expectancy thatâ€™s nearly 10 years shorter than the average Indian. And this is reported by Indian Medical Association. 

The primary causes are Cardiovascular disease and infections. Ironically, the very things they work tirelessly to prevent.

Endure 10-12 years of medical education with the only aspiration to save lives but be at the receiving end of stress, anxiety, and long working hours. And be a part of a system that doesnâ€™t give them time to care for their own health. The average Indian doctor clocks 60â€“80 hours a week and approx 300-400 doctors die by suicide every year. Mostly because of the impossible expectations they carry. It takes 10+ years of study before a doctor sees their first salary.

Theyâ€™re taught that saving lives is everything. After 10hrs+ of work, you can then go and figure your own personal health & family life. And after all this, theyâ€™re now told that AI will make them obsolete. That their jobs will be replaced by software tools because the system is inefficient.

I meet atleast 50 companies a month that pitch AI solutions for healthcare. These tools matter and they can make processes faster and improve accessibility. No doubt Indian healthcare needs better processes and better tech. But what it needs more than anything is empathy.

Indiaâ€™s hospitals are crowded and the health crisis is real. But whatâ€™s also been ignored is the mental and physical health of our doctors & medical staff. 

This isnâ€™t a rant against technology, AI or healthcare system. But a reminder to self and maybe a few who are reading this that without empathy and without recognizing the human cost, there will be no healthcare system left.

text:
Big fan of what Y Combinator has done for founders. But Iâ€™ve never understood the obsession with building a YC equivalent in India by investors here. Iâ€™m convinced it will never happen. Not because we lack talent or ambition, but because YC wasnâ€™t just a structure. It was the outcome of a rare mix of time, place, and cultural defaults.

YC emerged in a place where risk was cheap, talent was abundant, trust was a default & failure was celebrated as a credential. India has almost none of those ingredients in the same proportion yet.

Indian founders are world class at surviving, hacking & stretching resources. But YC worked because it taught founders to focus on scaling instead of surviving.
Indian early stage capital still acts like it's lending money , not taking risk. Even seed rounds come with board seats and monthly reporting. 

The genius of YC was its narrative monopoly. They created status & not just capital. Indiaâ€™s status economy works differently. You canâ€™t manufacture prestige in India without a IIT, IIM next to your name.

India wonâ€™t have its YC. But maybe thatâ€™s a good thing. 
What we need in India is founder first micro VCs with real skin in the game. A media and narrative engine that spotlights Indian builders solving Indian and world problems from India.

text:
Because we invest in healthcare, I get this question all the time: Will AI replace doctors? As a technology optimist I donâ€™t claim to have all the answers. But i feel this question usually reveals how little we understand both about AI & healthcare.

When people say AI will replace doctors and teachers in the next decade. They  assume that intelligence is enough to make an impact and forgets that trust is the real currency in both healthcare and education.

Doctors donâ€™t just prescribe, they hold your hand during a cancer diagnosis. Teachers donâ€™t just deliver content but they spot the kid falling behind, build confidence, and unlock potential. AI can assist, but it canâ€™t replace human empathy and trust.

So is AI important? Absolutely.
AI can read scans better than most radiologists. It can solve for homework & personalise lessons faster than a teacher. It can democratize access to world class knowledge, in any language, at near zero cost.

But can it replace the human relationship that sits at the core of these professions? AI doesnâ€™t replace doctors. It replaces inefficiencies around them. Likewise AI wonâ€™t replace teachers. But it can free them from admin so they can actually teach

Tech is best when itâ€™s invisible. When it supports human work & not erase it.
Yes, AI will change healthcare & education. The goal of AI shouldn't be to replace doctors & teachers. Itâ€™s to make a billion people feel like they finally have one. Thatâ€™s the real opportunity & thatâ€™s where the best builders will focus i feel.

posted_at.relative: 8 months ago â€¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
text:
Everyone today loves this grand narrative that "Tech will fix everything". Every week a news article or investor confidently declares that tech will fix healthcare & most entrepreneurs fall for this illusion of disruption. This narrative is doing more harm than good.

Most entrepreneurs today think, if we can build a beautifully designed app, use AI to chat, automate doctor-patient interactions, and scale it to millions of users, we can "solve" healthcare. 

It sounds great in a pitch deck. It almost never works in reality.

Why? Because healthcare isn't e-commerce. You canâ€™t scale a hospital bed like a food delivery fleet. You canâ€™t disrupt chronic disease with a better UI. You canâ€™t solve trust with a chatbot. Healthcare isnâ€™t a transaction, itâ€™s a relationship.

If you're serious about fixing healthcare, start thinking from first principles.

Everyone wants to build the â€œUber of Healthcare.â€ But Uber works because a ride from point A to B is a simple transaction. Healthcare isnâ€™t. You canâ€™t just match a patient with a doctor and assume the job is done. Don't build a generic doctor consultation app with a new UI or a marketplace that lists thousand doctor names. Focus on depth of care, outcomes, and follow-up treatments before chasing millions of users. Build a connected system that only focuses on driving outcomes.

Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics. AI can help a doctor diagnose faster. But it canâ€™t replace the doctor. Yet, doctors alone wonâ€™t solve Indiaâ€™s healthcare crisis. They also need trained frontline workers assisted by smart tech. Build AI tools to assist doctors enable faster diagnoses. Don't oversell your AI engine or LLM models to a patient. 

It doesnâ€™t matter if we have the best doctor or AI engine if the right medicine isnâ€™t available. Up to 20% of medicines sold in India are fake or substandard. Counterfeit drugs are a massive problem & the Pharma companies are growing this $58 billion market. Perhaps a great usecase to use AI and tech to streamline the supply chain. 

So, can tech fix healthcare? Yes. 
But not by replacing doctors, hospitals, or traditional care systems. The biggest healthcare opportunities in India are not about disruption but augmentation.

Tech alone wonâ€™t fix Indian healthcare. But finding the right places to apply can make a 10x difference. Healthcare isnâ€™t an industry that gets "disrupted" overnight. But it can be upgraded piece by piece, solving for what really matters. And if you understand that, youâ€™ll build something that actually works.

text:
Gopi is right. The reality is brutalâ€”less than 1% of aspiring athletes make it big, and even those who do are left with little security once their careers are over. Sports, like startups, have a power law distributionâ€”10% of players make 90% of the money. Everyone else is a statistic.

We love to read and watch the underdog storyâ€”the kid from nowhere who makes it to the top. But thatâ€™s survivorship bias. For every one success, there are tens of thousands who trained just as hard but got nothing. The real question is: why does sports have to be a gamble?

 If youâ€™re not in the top 1%, you donâ€™t get sponsorships, you donâ€™t have financial security, and once your career endsâ€”usually in your late 20â€™s or early 30sâ€”youâ€™re left scrambling for whatâ€™s next.

In developed nations, sports is a structured industry. There are leagues, second-tier careers, college scholarships, and post-career pathways. 

If you donâ€™t become an Olympic champion, you can still earn a living as a coach, analyst, trainer, or minor league player. The system doesnâ€™t discard you the moment youâ€™re not in the top 1%.

The problem isnâ€™t that sports is hardâ€”itâ€™s that failure is absolute. An engineer who fails at a startup can get a job. A failed athlete? They often have nothing. Thatâ€™s why in most countries without strong sports ecosystems, success in sports correlates with wealth. You canâ€™t afford to be an athlete unless you can afford to lose.

Right now, telling a poor kid to pursue sports is like telling them to buy lottery tickets as an investment strategy. Until we change that, Gopiâ€™s words will remain true. And thatâ€™s a failureâ€”not of the athletes, but of the system.

A great sports system doesnâ€™t just create championsâ€”it creates a nation of resilient, disciplined, and competitive people. And thatâ€™s the foundation of real development.

posted_at.relative: 9 months ago â€¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
text:
Building a business in preventive health is hard. No one tells you this upfront. I learned it the hard way, first as a founder, now as an investor.

Youâ€™ve chosen the harder game. Not because prevention doesnâ€™t work, but because people donâ€™t pay for it. Most wake up thinking about chai, parathas , deadlines, and school fees. Not long-term health. People today want instant gratificationâ€”sugar today, gym tomorrow.

Curative health makes money because illness is urgent. No one postpones a bypass surgery or negotiates an ICU bill. But prevention?Â Everyone hunts for gym discounts, coupon codes for healthy food and thinks twice before paying for a fitness program.

Hospitals & pharma companies thrive because they sell relief from suffering. And suffering is a guaranteed marketâ€”prevention is not.

Thatâ€™s why venture money chases curative healthâ€”it scales fast with clear unit economics, solving problems people canâ€™t ignore. Asking someone to eat better, sleep more, and exercise for a payoff 5â€“10 years later is like selling an FD over a lottery ticket. So accept this reality and build accordingly.

Yet, prevention is the hardest problem and the biggest untaped opportunity.
#1 Healthcare in India will shift to prevention-not because people suddenly care, but because not caring is becoming too expensive. 

#2 Your market isnâ€™t TAM, itâ€™s WTM (willing-to-pay market). Everyone should care about health, but few will pay for it.To go mass-market, make it cheaper than chai and as seamless as WhatsApp.

#3 If youâ€™re selling prevention, reposition it. People donâ€™t buy prevention. They buy status, performance, and convenience. Make it aspirational & competitive.

#4 Trust in health isnâ€™t built overnight. People wonâ€™t change their habits because you raised venture money. Youâ€™re in the business of delayed gratification. That means slow &sustainable growth.

#5 If your product doesnâ€™t make people healthier or keep them engaged long-term, the number of app downloads doesn't matter. Focus on retention, real outcomes and revenueâ€”not GMV, DAUs or metrics to make a pitch deck look good. 

If you can do this, you wonâ€™t just build a businessâ€”youâ€™ll change how India thinks about health. And thatâ€™s worth building for.

posted_at.relative: 1 year ago â€¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
text:
Have met over 600+ healthcare startups this year at Rainmatter. These are my general observations of the sector in 2024 so far. An investor & health enthusiast perspective. 

Remember, these are observations and not opinions.  If youâ€™re a builder, I'm always keen to exchange notes.

1) Health tech needs maturing â€“ The novelty phase of tech meets health is over and the focus should be on driving outcomes to the user.

2) Preventive health is gaining traction â€“ More startups are focused on preventive solutions.

3) Nutrition personalisation is heating up â€“ Companies are going beyond generic consulting and leveraging DNA, microbiome, or other personal data for nutrition recommendations.

4) UPI for health not yet in India- ABDM use cases haven't seen much adoption.

5) Wearables are no longer the star â€“ Smartwatches and rings are still strong but are considered table stakes. Consumers want something that tells â€œwhyâ€ and not limited to â€œwhatâ€.

6) Corporate wellness is an overrated market â€“ With rising mental health issues, stress, and burnout in the workforce, B2B wellness solutions ideally should show promise. But there isnâ€™t adoption from corporates.

7) The â€œbiohackingâ€ trend is niche but growing â€“longevity startups are speculative but hot.  Increasing interest in biohacking protocols (sleep optimization, anti ageing etc.). But the market is niche and often hard to validate scientifically unless clinical protocols are done.

8) Consumer trust in health supplements is dwindling â€“ The supplement industry lacks regulation and transparency and this has eroded trust amongst consumers. Brands are focusing on science-backed products.

9) AI in healthcare â€“ Many are bullish on AIâ€™s potential to revolutionise diagnostics, patient care, and drug discovery, but deployment in clinical settings is slow and capital-intensive.

10) Mental health is booming â€“ Digital mental health startups, especially those offering therapy, coaching, or CBT solutions are seeing adoptions but differentiation is becoming a challenge in a crowded market.

11) Community-driven fitness â€“ Social, community-oriented fitness solutions still have potential if done right especially those blending real-world interactions with digital offerings.

12) CAC is a challenge for D2C health brands â€“ Brands are facing rising customer acquisition costs often with no sustainable GTM.

13) Hybrid health businesses are scaling better â€“ Companies combining digital and physical services have better scope of scaling fast.

14) Telehealth plateaued â€“ The initial excitement around telehealth has subsided for both consumers and investors.

15) Health marketplaces have no moat â€“ Platforms connecting consumers with healthcare providers or wellness services are overrated with no clear moat to grow.

There are more thoughts on this. Because of the word limit on Linkedin , can't post the remaining here. Read the whole list on https://lnkd.in/g-CTY4zC

posted_at.relative: 1 year ago â€¢ Edited â€¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
text:
An unpopular opinion about founders/VC's building and investing in health category. This may disappoint a few.

First, if you are a founder building in the health. You've to walk the talk. 
What does that mean? You have to be healthy and fit. 

-The biggest moat in the health industry is trust. This can't be built by performance marketing or hiring influencers. 
-Why will a customer trust your product if the founder isn't healthy? You don't need six packs. But you shouldn't look unfit.
-If your product came out from your own problem statement, great. Tell the world how you got there and share your experience. 
-In health industry you scale by not selling features. But by earning the trust. 

Second, don't pitch or raise money from an investor who doesn't walk the talk. 

-To build a scalable business TAM is important. But impact is most important.
- If the first question they ask is, how large is the business and not why you choose to build the product. That's a sign.
- If an investor doesn't make an effort to experience your product or service and offer genuine feedback. They are truly not investing in you. But chasing vanity.
- Have seen many VC events ending with alcohol and the food corner filled with junk. And that happens because they don't walk the talk and perhaps staying healthy is not their top priority in personal life. 

That's it. Hope this changes. And we build businesses and products that brings impact on people. And trust is your anchor to scale.

text:
23 million girls in India drop out of school annually due to a lack of proper menstrual hygiene facilities.

More than 300 million women in India still don't have access to proper menstrual hygiene products. And still use old rags, ash, leaves & clothes. 

Was talking to Vikas Bagaria yesterday to understand the current situation. 

While brands will do their bit to build awareness. The biggest impact will happen when we start talking about it at home, office and in social circles. 

-Celebrating one women's day in a year doesn't do any good. 
-Men should be comfortable in breaking the silence and engage in conversations with their daughter, sister, spouse & friends. 
-Menstruation education should be everyone's business. Awareness amongst girl child is good. But should be equally important amongst young boys. 

Ignorance is the real taboo. Menstruation education is a collective responsibility. 
This video came up later internally and thought it's apt to share here.

text:
Employee wellness neednâ€™t be complicated. 

Thatâ€™s Nithin, Vishnu & me crossing the finish line at IronMan Goa last month.
We participated as a corporate relay team. 

Working in a 9am-6pm work environment can be stressful. Be it corporates or startups. Employers want their teams to be healthy. And employees want to live a healthy life.Â 
The mismatch is in expectations.

Most employers over complicate employee wellness by pushing for programs that don't sync with everyone. But sometimes the biggest impact is driven by doing simple things. 

At Zerodha & Rainmatter playing sports is an anchor that has worked well.
Not just evangelising it but participation from top leadership to everyone in the company. 

For those interested how we do this internally. This is a link to the forum where we discussed everything from event planning, creating a team, training and more. We had three teams and everyone met each other only at the event :) 

Link: https://lnkd.in/giV8PgBA

The upside is, now we have more folks doing events for running, triathlons, obstacle racing and more. There are groups playing some sport every weekend. And all this without any complicated employee wellness program. 
People just talk to each other, signup events and show up to the start line. 

Becoming a healthy company is not an event.
It's a process.

text:
GOALS
They look far and hazy unless you keep chasing them. 
Every day, every week, every month.


In 2020, I set a goal to run a Sub 3hr marathon. 
For 4months, I was chasing this goal. It was up on my wall ðŸ˜Š 
To become Sub 3 marathoner.

And every week, I got two inch closer.

Iâ€™ll wake up and stare at the wall reminiscing all the past training and before going to bed muster whatever left for the next day.

Marathon training is just learning to be bored while you're hurting. 

Did i meet my goal? ...Yes, I finished 2:59:52 ðŸ˜Œ 
But those 16 weeks changed me a lot.
as an entrepreneur,
as a colleague,
as a husband,
as a friend,
and as an athlete.

There are maybe 100 men in India who can run Sub3hr marathon.
I'm one of them.
Today a 2:55:58 Marathoner.
Head high, heart full.

Everyone teaches motivation. But no one learns discipline.
Motivation is in abundance. Discipline is scarce. 

The progress in your goals is the gap between your desire and commitment. 

This is the exact training plan i followed to become a Sub3hr marathoner ðŸ˜Š ðŸ‘‡

We are on a mission to build the most convenient fitness solution. We are reimagining #onlinefitness by partnering with fitness & yoga trainers around the world. 

Selvan, Deepti and I are lucky to have a talented team and hope together we build a rocketship. Thanks, Nithin & Raghunandan for the support!
